original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā sāvatthiyam viharati jetavane anāthapiṇḍikassa ārāme
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling at Sāvatthī in Jeta’s Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Park.

original: Atha kho āyasmā rāhulo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā rāhulo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmā rāhulaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmā rāhulaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then the venerable Rāhula went to the Blessed One, and after paying homage to him, he sat down at one side and said to the Blessed One:

original: “sādhu me, bhante, bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammaṁ desetu, yamahaṁ bhagavato dhammaṁ sutvā eko vūpakaṭṭho appamatto ātāpī pahitatto vihareyyan”ti.
analyzed: sādhu me bhante bhagavā saṅkhittena dhammam desetu yam aham bhagavataḥ dhammam sutvā ekaḥ vūpakaṭṭhaḥ appamattaḥ ātāpī pahitattaḥ vihareyyanti
translated: “Venerable sir, it would be good if the Blessed One would teach me the Dhamma in brief, so that, having heard the Dhamma from the Blessed One, I might dwell alone, withdrawn, diligent, ardent, and resolute.”

analyzed: cakkhum niccam vā aniccam vā ati
translated: Is the eye permanent or impermanent?”

original: “Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti?
analyzed: yam pana aniccam dukkham vā tam sukham vā ati
translated: “But if it is impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”

original: “Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ:

translated: ‘This is mine, this I am, this is my self’?”

analyzed: evam passa rāhula sutavā ariya sāvako cakkhusmim pi nibbindati pe sotasmim pi
translated: “Rāhula, when a noble disciple has seen this thus as it actually is with proper wisdom, he becomes disenchanted with the eye, disenchanted with the ear,🔽disenchanted with the nose, disenchanted with the tongue,

original: nibbindati … ghānasmimpi nibbindati … jivhāyapi nibbindati … kāyasmimpi nibbindati
analyzed: nibbindati ghānasmim pi nibbindati jivhāya api nibbindati kāyasmim pi nibbindati

analyzed: nibbindam virajjati virāgā vimuccati vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: Through disenchantment, he becomes dispassionate. Through dispassion, he is released. When he is released, he knows he is released.

original: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.🔽(Etena peyyālena dasa suttantā kātabbā.)
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti iti  etena peyyālena dasa suttantā kātabbā
translated: He understands: ‘Destroyed is birth, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming back to any state of being.’”
(The ten suttas of this vagga should be elaborated in the same way as the first.)

analyzed: rūpā niccā vā aniccā vā ati

original: “evaṁ passaṁ, rāhula, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpesupi nibbindati … saddesupi nibbindati
analyzed: evam passa rāhula sutavā ariya sāvako rūpesu pi nibbindati saddesu pi nibbindati
translated: “Rāhula, when you see in this way, your mind will be repelled by forms, repelled by sounds,

original: … gandhesupi nibbindati … rasesupi nibbindati … phoṭṭhabbesupi nibbindati … dhammesupi nibbindati;🔽nibbindaṁ virajjati …pe…
analyzed: gandhesu pi nibbindati rasesu pi nibbindati phoṭṭhabbesu pi nibbindati dhammesu pi nibbindati  nibbindam virajjati pe
translated: repelled by smells, repelled by tastes, repelled by tactile objects, and repelled by thoughts.

Being repelled, you will become dispassionate. Through dispassion, you will be released. When you are released, you will know and see that you are released. You will understand: ‘Destroyed is birth, the spiritual life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming back to any state of being.’“

translated: “Rāhula, when a learned noble disciple has seen this as it really is with right wisdom, his mind becomes dispassionate towards the eye,🔽dispassionate towards the ear,🔽dispassionate towards the nose,🔽dispassionate towards the tongue,

original: Atha kho āyasmā rāhulo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā rāhulo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmā rāhulaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmā rāhulaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then the venerable Rahula went to the Blessed One, and after paying homage to him, he sat down at one side and said to him:

original: “kathaṁ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṁ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti?🔽“Yaṁ kiñci, rāhula, rūpaṁ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṁ
analyzed: katham nu kho bhante jānato katham passato imasmin ca sa viññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabba nimittesu ahaṅkāra mamaṅkāra māna anusayāḥ na honti iti  yam kiñci rāhula rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vā oḷārika
translated: “Venerable sir, how should one know, how should one see so that, in regard to this body with consciousness and in regard to all external signs, I-making, mine-making, and the underlying tendency to conceit no longer occur within?”

original: vā sukhumaṁ vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā, sabbaṁ rūpaṁ ‘netaṁ mama,🔽nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya passati.🔽Yā kāci vedanā …pe…
analyzed: vā sukhumam vā hīnam vā paṇītam vā yam dūre santike vā sabbam rūpam na itam mama  na iso ham asmi na mā iso attā ati evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya passati  yā kāci vedanā pe
translated: “Any kind of material form whatever, Rahula, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near - one sees all material form as it really is with correct wisdom thus: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’🔽Any kind of feeling whatever…
Any kind of volitional formations whatever…

original: yaṁ kiñci viññāṇaṁ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ
analyzed: yam kiñci viññāṇam atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikam vā
translated: Any kind of consciousness whatever, whether past, future, or present, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near - one sees all consciousness as it really is with correct wisdom thus: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’

original: vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā, sabbaṁ viññāṇaṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi,🔽na meso attā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya passati.
analyzed: vā hīnam vā paṇītam vā yam dūre santike vā sabbam viññāṇam na itam mama na isī ham asmi  na mā iso attā ati evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya passati
translated: whether coarse or fine, inferior or excellent, whether far or near: all consciousness is not self, nor is the self one who possesses consciousness, nor is the self subject to consciousness.

original: Evaṁ kho, rāhula, jānato evaṁ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho rāhula jānataḥ evam passataḥ imasmin ca sa viññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabba nimittesu ahaṅkāra mamaṅkāra māna anusayāḥ na honti iti
translated: Thus, Rāhula, through truly seeing and fully understanding this, the conceit ‘I am’ is abandoned in him, the conceit ‘I am not’ does not arise, and the conceit ‘I am this’ does not take place.”

original: Atha kho āyasmā rāhulo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho āyasmā rāhulo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu āyasmā rāhulaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantam abhivādetvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu āyasmā rāhulaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then the venerable Rāhula went to the Blessed One, and after paying homage to him, he sat down at one side and asked him:

original: “kathaṁ nu kho, bhante, jānato kathaṁ passato imasmiṁ ca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā
analyzed: katham nu kho bhante jānato katham passato imasmin ca sa viññāṇake kāye bahiddhā
translated: “Venerable sir, when one knows and sees what, are the conceit ‘I am,’ the desire ‘I am,’ and the underlying tendency ‘I am’ abandoned in the world?

original: ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṁ mānasaṁ hoti vidhā samatikkantaṁ santaṁ suvimuttan”ti?
analyzed: ca sabba nimittesu ahaṅkāra mamaṅkāra māna apagatam mānasam hoti vidhā samatikkantam santam su vimuttam ti
translated: and his mind is free from the conceit ‘I am’ regarding all signs, has transcended discrimination, is peaceful, and well-liberated.”

original: “Yaṁ kiñci, rāhula, rūpaṁ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṁ🔽vā sukhumaṁ vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā sabbaṁ rūpaṁ ‘netaṁ mama,🔽nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya disvā anupādā vimutto hoti.🔽Yā kāci vedanā …pe…
analyzed: yam kiñci rāhula rūpam atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vā oḷārika  vā sukhumam vā hīnam vā paṇītam vā yam dūre santike vā sabbam rūpam na itam mama  na iso ham asmi na mā iso attā ati evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya disvā anupādā vimuttaḥ hoti  yā kāci vedanā pe
translated: “Whatever material form there is—whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—a monk sees all material form as it really is with correct wisdom in this way: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’ When he sees it like this, he becomes disenchanted with material form, dispassionate towards it, and released from it.🔽Whatever feeling there is—whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—a monk sees all feeling as it really is with correct wisdom in this way: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’ When he sees it like this, he becomes disenchanted with feeling, dispassionate towards it, and released from it.

original: yā kāci saññā …🔽ye keci saṅkhārā …🔽yaṁ kiñci viññāṇaṁ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ🔽vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā, sabbaṁ viññāṇaṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi,
analyzed: yā kāci saññā  ye keci saṅkhārāḥ  yam kiñci viññāṇam atīta anāgata paccuppannam ajjhattam vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikam vā  vā hīnam vā paṇītam vā yam dūre santike vā sabbam viññāṇam na itam mama na isī ham asmi
translated: Whatever perception there is—whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—a monk sees all perception as it really is with correct wisdom in this way: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’ When he sees it like this, he becomes disenchanted with perception, dispassionate towards it, and released from it.🔽Whatever intentional activities there are—whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—a monk sees all intentional activities as they really are with correct wisdom in this way: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’ When he sees it like this, he becomes disenchanted with intentional activities, dispassionate towards them, and released from them.

original: na meso attā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya disvā anupādā vimutto hoti.
analyzed: na mā isaḥ attā ati evam etam yathābhūtam sammappaññāya disvā anupādā vimuttaḥ hoti
translated: Whatever consciousness there is—whether past, present, or future, internal or external, gross or subtle, inferior or superior, far or near—a monk sees all consciousness as it really is with correct wisdom in this way: ‘This is not mine, this I am not, this is not my self.’ When he sees it like this, he becomes disenchanted with consciousness, dispassionate towards it, and released from it.

original: Evaṁ kho, rāhula, jānato evaṁ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānāpagataṁ mānasaṁ hoti vidhā samatikkantaṁ santaṁ suvimuttan”ti.
analyzed: evam kho rāhula jānataḥ evam passataḥ imasmin ca sa viññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabba nimittesu ahaṅkāra mamaṅkāra māna apagatam mānasam hoti vidhā samatikkantam santam su vimuttam ti
translated: It is when one knows and sees in this way that one’s mind is freed from the taint of sensual desire, freed from the taint of being, freed from the taint of ignorance. When it is freed, there comes the knowledge: ‘It is freed.’ One understands: ‘Birth is ended, the holy life fulfilled, the task done. There is nothing further for this world.’”
The second sub-chapter on Rāhula is finished.🔽The summary:
And the underlying tendency, and the abandoning,
The sub-chapter is declared to be that.
